subject: Gardening
title: Ryoan-ji: The Art of Emptiness
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Ryoan-ji: The Art of Emptiness.

hook.text: Fifteen rocks on white gravel. No plants, no water, no color. Ryoan-ji is the world's most debated garden.

buildup.text: Created around 1500 in Kyoto, the garden measures only 30 by 10 meters. Monks rake the gravel daily.

discovery.text: The rocks are arranged so that from any seated position, at least one rock is always hidden from view.

twist.text: Nobody knows who designed it or what it means. Theories include islands in a sea, tigers crossing water, and infinity.

climax.text: Ryoan-ji's power lies in what's absent. Emptiness invites the viewer's mind to create its own meaning.

punchline.text: The garden's meaning is whatever you bring to it.

quiz.question: What is unique about the rock arrangement at Ryoan-ji?
options: The rocks form a perfect circle when viewed from above
At least one rock is always hidden from any seated viewing position
Each rock represents a specific Japanese deity
